reviews.review_text: 'You're it until you're dead or I find someone better!'  Spiders and ticks and ants, OH MY! Where do I start? Bugs, guns, some kind of invisible wall? Seriously fun game that doesn't take itself too serious. This game is well worth the full price.  A third person shooter that's easy to pick up and as fun to play solo as it is with friends. Select one of four unique armors, choose from over 200 weapons, and get ready to kick some major bug butt.  Once on the field, the commentary between allies and the tips provided by the higher ups will have you laughing everytime.  As for those that typically avoid ports for their many faults and issues, you'll find none of that here. Outside of one spelling error this game is near flawless. Complete key binding, full controller support, and satasfactory graphics settings.  So click 'ADD TO CART' and join team lightning today!

I'm a big fan of EDF 2017 on 360 and Global Defence Force on ps2 but I can't really recommend this one.  First complaint, no split screen co-op. I ended up buying 2 copies during a sale so my gf and I could play together.  Second, lame tone/aesthetic. This game was developed by Vicious Cycle Software, a western developer who, from what I can tell, has never made a decent game. They took the kaiju tone of the originals and tried to turn it into a meathead military game. Gone is the simplicity of shooting and diving. Gone are the slightly too loud sound effects of picking up power-ups and navigating the menus. Gone are the physics that result in bouncing ant carcasses. Gone is the awful dialogue spouted by your fellow soldiers, well maye not gone but not as enjoyably terrible. The missions are longer and this may appeal to some but I prefer the plentiful bite size missions of the previous games.  It's just a let down. They managed to take the awesome concept of 'shoot giant insects' and get it wrong. I didn't think it was possible.
EDF Insect Armageddon is a destructible third person shooter with tons of guns and thousands of alien bugs to shoot. As an EDF fan I enjoyed it a lot!

This game is one of the MOST under rater shooters of our time. It doesn't have the best graphics, no... But why in the hell should that matter if your looking for a FANTASTIC game.   The game revolves around big ♥♥♥ alien bugs and machines, massive explossions that can and WILL level every building in sight. The bugs are BIG, BAD, and they SWARM. If there was ever an enemy that uses it's numbers to overwhelm you, this is it.  There are 4 main classes, and ALL of them are unbeleivably well balanced. Want a Jet pack? Check. How about a heavy with an energy sheild that absorbs damage, shocks enemies, and if surrounded detonates a small nuke? Check. Or how about a sniper who can massicare the massive swarm of enemies from afar without ever smelling them? Check... or how about your average Joe soldier who just HAPPENS to be able to hold every kind of weapon imaginable? Check.  The weapons... oh the weapons. So many weapons and gun turrets and oh, did I mention they have tanks? No? Well they do... and sometimes, you will need them. BAD. especially when your up against enemies that are a little over 15 stories tall and shoot lazers out their asses while dropping giant jumping spiders who happen to have giant ant friends, that have flying hornet friends... and yest they're also giant... who happen to have flying machines that swarm and suicide bomb you when they're too damaged to fight... who happen to have more friends who are just bigger... and Biggers... and BIGGER... You see where I'm going with this?  Oh yes and... there is a rocket launcher that happens to be able to level 6 city blocks...   But hey if your not into that sort of fast paced, unforgiving, brutal, and adreniline pumping action with 3 player co-op then hey. I guess this game just isn't for you. You probably couldn't handle Inferno difficulty anyways ;P

Now here's one of those inexpensive little hidden gems. There's an art to making monsters look and FEEL larger than life, and this game has mastered that art. The co-op is just great and so are the controls. Very natural feeling. Ever wanted to play Starship Troopers the game? Well this is your chance. GO EARTH DEFENSE FORCE! GO!

The concept is grand, the game isn't ugly, and there's a lot of extremely hammy content that make this game worth a try. BUT the one glaring issue is that the game is horrifically repetitive- generic enemies, bosses, special enemies, and character arsenal all start to blend together after a while, creating an experience that dries out quickly.
Amazing. Just amazing. I never want to stop playing this.

To be honest, I have a mixed feelings about this game. It's even hard to convey it in my native language, let alone in English.  On one hand, Insect Armageddon feels like it wanted to give us something huge. Not just huge insect and robots and insect-robots, but also in terms of contents. Huge maps, destroyable building, neat variety of weapons, limited range of classes that compliments each other. But everything fell short. Not to mention you REALLY need to grind to unlock all the weapons, buy them, and fully upgrade the clasess. Everything just end up repetitive as hell. The 'story mode' is pretty damn short too. Although that's not really a problem for this type of game since the main point is replayability. But the drive to replaying quickly died down when I'm slogging through same looking maps and same variety of enemies, hunting down mystery weapon boxes hoping 10-20 minutes you're spending would be worthwhile. Even though you could make a meal, go to ATM to pay some bills, clean your laptop or keyboard, write a blog post, shave, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ing somewhere, stalk your crush, or simply masturbating to your lovely waifu in those time.   In the end of the day I still enjoyed it, but (while having no expectations in the first place) it's still kinda disappointing. Still, there's not much mindless murder simulator on PC aside from Insect Armageddon and Samurai/Dynasty Warrior. And having alien bugs as enemies does feels pretty refreshing, the only thing that could make this better if there's also bug-space-dinosaur enemies thrown into the mix. Not worth $10 though, but I doubt Bandai Namco would give a f-- I mean, give a price drop for this game. Or for their other 'Westernized' game from their franchise on Steam. I just bought it full price hoping for another PC/Steam release for their games. Preferably the 'too-Japanese' one. I mean, Japanese devs with or without the help from small US publishers are starting to flock into this damn DRM platform, right? And they did put a translated rhythm game and one single album to US/International iTunes, right? There is always hope, right? RIGHT?

Although, to find all of the weapons, and to lvl up every 'armor' (class), you need countless amounts of hours, which is kinda sad... Despite that i don't get fed up with repetitiveness quickly, after basically 25+ hours of grinding ONE LAST WEAPON, I'm sick of this game. kthxbai.

I was sceptical; Its a console port from an not well known studio. But this game really suprised me, its a bit like Serious Sam, but with Bugs and Aliens.  You cant approach this game with high expectations, because then it will not deliver. The graphics are surley not awesome or great, they do their job neverthless. This is a solid port all in all, keys can be reassigned, resolutions can be set.  Framerate seems to be capped, not good, but with all the action youre probably too busy to notice it. I encountered no crashes or technical problems... but millions of BUGS ;)  Its addicting, you unlock weapons and levels for your class. You can play the campagin and a survival mode, off- and online with online co-op. (havent tried online yet).  If you are looking for cheap, mindless action, lots of explosions, the ability to flatten whole cities and kill tons of bugs and aliens - this is it. No thinking, planning or strategy... Just you, lots of guns and the Bugs.

Earth Defense Force: Insect Armageddon is a semi-reboot of the series and is the only game in the series not made by the original developers Sandlot. It takes place around the same time of EDF 2017 and is set in the city of New Detroit. Upon starting the game you can either choose to play the game by yourself or create a new online game for people to join. If you decide to go it alone you will be accompanied by two AI bots named Kid and Cyrus who are not entirely useless but nowhere near as helpful as real players. You can then choose from one of four classes to play as. The Trooper who is your jack of all trades with no real special talents, the Tactical who can lay down turrets and mines, the Battle who is essentially a walking tank with the biggest and most destructive weapons and finally the Jet who can zoom around in a jetpack.  Each class has a different set of weapons exclusive to them and with the addition of being able to change your armor to a few different colors it helps making each class feel unique. So far the game is looking awesome and you eagerly jump into mission 1. The first thing you will likely notice is that this game looks much better than the previous entries and every enemy has been resigned to fit this new, gritty theme it's going for. Personally I actually prefer this art direction compared to the previous entries and it makes it all the more of a shame when you actually start playing it. You see they decided to add RPG mechanics by gathering experience and leveling up your character but the problem lies in that you'll start off completely rubbish.  Your gun barely does any damage, the clip for each weapon is insanely small meaning that you'll be reloading 80% of the time since this is a game about fighting hordes of enemies and probably worst of all is how the Jet class starts off. You know how he has a jetpack? Well yeah, starting off you can very likely jump higher in real life than that thing lifts him off the ground which is just sad to look at and turns him into a glorified roller-skater. 7 hours of playing nearly exclusively as this class and his jetpack is noticeably better after leveling a few times but don't expect to be able to reach most of the surrounding rooftops for a vantage point.  One of the selling points of the game is that it features 300 guns. Well that too is messed up by this completely unnecessary leveling system since whenever you pick up a gun crate from the battlefield they are inexplicably unable to be used until you reach a certain level. Not only does that take the fun out of collecting loot since it takes so long to level up but it also means you will be forced to stick with your rubbish weaponry due to bad game design. Another thing that is really strange is that every weapon of a category looks exactly the same. As an example the first rocket launcher looks the same as the latest rocket launcher you just picked up, the latest assault rifle does too and every other gun has a single weapon model for its entire category. This makes the feel of finally leveling up and being able to use a new gun all the more disappointing.  Using explosives in the midst of battle is still as satisfying as ever since every building is completely destructible and by the end of a mission most of the city will be in ruins due to fierce fighting. Unfortunately these new and improved graphics do come at a great cost. There are red “invisible walls” everywhere and you will quickly notice how small the area you can actually play in are. The game tries to hide this fact by drastically changing how missions are designed. While most of the mission from the previous games set you in a huge environment and tasked you with simply surviving the onslaught, this game is chock filled with way-points you must head to. Go to a certain area and switch a beacon or something equally mundane, fight a horde, then go switch another beacon and rinse and repeat until the game finishes.  This gets old fast and since there are only 15 missions in this game, each of them last quite some time further making the repetition noticeable. The worst part of it all is that this game switched from the cheesy, plain dumb dialogue of the rest of the series and instead went the dull, serious route. I found the dialogue plain unbearable and most every word you hear out of someone’s mouth will be a random string of words like “Bravo Zulu Lightning over” or “Affirmative, Oscar Bravo Lightning Strike”. I guess they were trying to make it sound cool and edgy but it just sounds like a bunch of things kids would say when they take a match of CS:GO far too seriously.  Moving back to the topic of compromises caused by the improved graphics, the amount of enemies that can be on the screen at any one time has been greatly reduced. To give the illusion of facing a horde of enemies they now spawn right around you by crawling out of the ground. This could have been cool if it was used a few times but that is how most of your encounters play out. You go to a way point, receive a string of random words from the mission handler and then enemies predictably pop out of nowhere instantly surrounding you time and time again. Gone are the days when you see hundreds of ants marching to your location as you desperately pick off as many as you can before they reach you. Yes the previous games had graphics right out of the original Xbox but this is a prime case in where graphics are not everything.  Ant hills make a return and still spawn in infinite number of enemies until destroyed. Yes, they messed that up too as you are likely imagining. No longer can you destroy the hill with your rocket launcher that is capable of destroying several skyscrapers with a single blast, now you must walk up right next to the hill and plant a tiny charge on the outside. The worst part of this is that it takes several seconds to set it up and a single hit causes you to start all over again. This was clearly designed to “enhance” coop by forcing your friends to cover you but with how fast most weapons run out of ammo, it's likely they simply won't be able to in many cases. Friendly fire is always on and you will take damage if you mindlessly run in front of a friend that is firing his gun. Your AI companions if playing solo are pretty good at not shooting you but seem to constantly try to get themselves killed when you are firing.  If you are downed they can revive you and you will be back at full health. Once you finish the campaign you will have the option to turn off the AI bots in future playthroughs. You will also unlock a “campaign remix” mode that randomizes the enemies encountered. Not really a mode that makes much of a difference to the missions. You also have survival mode where you can play with up to 6 other players and fight until you all drop. In survival you can only play as the Trooper class, gain no experience and none of your guns from campaign can be used. One thing I must praise this game for is that vehicles are now finally helpful and no longer have controls designed by someone that has never played a video game. It is pretty fun to ride in tanks, mechs or just get into anti-air turrets. There are quite a few new awesome looking enemies added as well. At the end of the day I get the feeling that Insect Armageddon wasn't even originally supposed to be an EDF game due to how badly they messed up the basic features this series is known for. It may be fun for a bit if you plan on playing with some friends but I just cannot recommend it.

Earth Defense Force: Insect Armageddon

Just to be upfront, I'm new to the series and this is my first taste of it.  Giant insects & spiders? ✓ A variety of character loadouts? ✓ Swarms of aliens from outer space? ✓ Mechs? ✓ A giant monster that barrels in like a meteor from space? ✓ Destructable enviroments? ✓  Earth Defense Force: Insect Armageddon is a pretty fun game if I do say so myself.   There are some negatives to point out. EDF is a little repetative in its objectives. Essentially you're moving from point to point, killing swarms, and that's the crux of it. Another negative to point out is that the dialogue is pretty corny and cheesy. Your squad-mates chime in with very cringey things to say and it's not even funny; you'll involuntarily sigh when you hear them . Also your character's name is 'Lightning'....yeah.  With that being said, if you're able to ignore the negatives, this is a very fun title. EDF: Insect Armageddon is a pretty neat gem on Steam. It's worth a look.

Much better than expected. It's defininitely been 'Americanized', but that's not entirely bad. I spent most of my time killing things and it was fun, which is all that's important for this kind of game.
It's EDF American edition. Game is a lot shorter than I would have liked, and there is much less in the way of weapons. The different classes were cool but felt super limited.

You know how some games are great because they are varied and intelligent, and artistic, and blablabla? THIS IS NOT THE CASE: EDF is like that time when you got really drunk on a Death Metal show, and by that I mean, if you try to remember how you could do that or why you did, you can't, but somehow you know you felt awesome. By that I mean, this is an arcade game, like Robotron or Smash TV, with the giant insects from Starship Troopers and every cheesy science fiction b-movie ever made. It's not a game to be invested, it's a game to have fun. GREAT fun. Go destroy some spiders now.

Earth Defense Force: Insect Armageddon is a good, solid 3rd person shooter. Try to protect the Earth from an invasion of giant insects and see how far you can get.  Customise the colors of your uniforms, unlock and earn a wide variety of weapons for the four classes in the game.  I don't know about the multi-player aspect of Earth Defense Force: Insect Armageddon as I only play solo, but the single player campaign and survival mode are bolth excelent. If you like being in the thick of heavy action against grim odds with barely a chance to catch your breath, you might like this...at least until you end up running down the street in a blind panic with a tick the size of a bean-bag chair on your back.

It's an inexpensive, mindless, 3rd person shoooter. I've dumped hundreds of hours into the Xbox 360 version of this game including it's predecessor. It's got a ♥♥♥♥ ton of guns, nearly everything is destructable, lots of giant insects to kill, and GIANT ♥♥♥♥ING MECHS! It can get repetitive playing single player, but that's what co-op is for. This game will not let you down.
